status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.
status.name: Open

worklogs.comment:
pearu commented on pull request #3876: ARROW-4825: [WIP][C++][Python] Transition from MemoryPool* to shared_ptr<MemoryPool>&
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3876
 
 
   This PR implements MemoryPool storage using shared_ptr to ensure that MemoryPool will be kept alive until all its Buffers are deallocated.
   
   Fixes [ARROW-4825](https://github.com/Quansight/arrow/pull/new/arrow-4825).
   
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

   I'm -1 on this one. This is a very invasive change. I will continue the discussion in JIRA.

wesm commented on issue #3876: ARROW-4825: [WIP][C++][Python] Transition from MemoryPool* to shared_ptr<MemoryPool>&
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3876#issuecomment-472177320
 
 
   We'll need to spend some time discussing this given the scope and invasiveness of it. I would like to see if there are other ways to address the root problem which is a _new_ memory pool being created in Python and then being garbage collected as a result of user code. I think this issue can be addressed with changes that are less invasive and do not require changing any APIs

wesm commented on issue #3876: ARROW-4825: [WIP][C++][Python] Transition from MemoryPool* to shared_ptr<MemoryPool>&
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3876#issuecomment-472177778
 
 
   For example, `MemoryPool` may internally create a private `shared_ptr<MemoryBank>` object which is shared between the `MemoryPool` and `PoolBuffer` instances. This can be done in a fully transparent way
   
   This is BTW the way that we extend the lifetime of memory maps beyond the lifetime of a `MemoryMappedFile` instance

pearu commented on issue #3876: ARROW-4825: [WIP][C++][Python] Transition from MemoryPool* to shared_ptr<MemoryPool>&
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3876#issuecomment-472208079
 
 
   I admit, modifying ca 200 files per PR is invasive.
   However, my pleas are:
   1. using `shared_ptr<MemoryPool>` instead of `MemoryPool*` seems the right thing to do because it guarantees the proper destruction order of objects that hold the `MemoryPool` pointer without any workarounds (such as MemoryBank, if I understand it correctly).
   2. the change from `MemoryPool*` to `shared_ptr<MemoryPool>` turned out to be trivial: there are only few coding patterns that required changes and all the updated unittests pass successfully.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

wesm commented on issue #3876: ARROW-4825: [WIP][C++][Python] Transition from MemoryPool* to shared_ptr<MemoryPool>&
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3876#issuecomment-472210269
 
 
   What I like least about this is that semantics from bindings layers are influencing the C++ API. That doesn't seem right to me. In many data processing applications, the memory manager is a component that is central to runtime state management. It is the application's responsibility to ensure that the `MemoryPool` stays alive longer than the memory allocated from it. 
   
   The other big problem with this application is that we do have quite a lot of C++ API users. I can see breaking / deprecating an API here or there but not breaking dozens of APIs all at once. I think we should investigate our options, staying focused on the goals at hand (making sure that code written in Python does not segfault), and avoid unnecessary refactoring creep. 
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

users@infra.apache.org

   The other big problem with this change is that we do have quite a lot of C++ API users. I can see breaking / deprecating an API here or there but not breaking dozens of APIs all at once. fsaintjacques commented on issue #3876: ARROW-4825: [WIP][C++][Python] Transition from MemoryPool* to shared_ptr<MemoryPool>&
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3876#issuecomment-472212234
 
 
   Or have a wrapping allocator that stacks the allocated buffers and explicitly delete them, this could be simplified with context guard:
   
   ```
   with allocator() as pool:
     #  push buf to pool._buffers
     buf = pool.allocate(...)
   
   # allocator goes out of scope, pool.__exit__ calls `map(lambda x: del x, pool._buffers)` ensure they're deleted before pool.

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3876#issuecomment-472213029
 
 
   I agree, there are many ways to workaround the current issue without changing Arrow at all. However, the use-case giving the segfault is something that would be very natural to use for most users, IMHO.

wesm commented on issue #3876: ARROW-4825: [WIP][C++][Python] Transition from MemoryPool* to shared_ptr<MemoryPool>&
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3876#issuecomment-472237446
 
 
   It depends. Many applications will never touch the MemoryPool API and simply use `arrow::default_memory_pool()`. I would regard using custom memory pools as fairly advanced usage and should require an awareness of runtime state management. In database systems, such runtime state is often managed by some kind of singleton object, and memory is managed very carefully in different components of the project. Since pyarrow is a developer-centric library rather than a user-centric one I would expect a higher level of sophistication from its user than something like pandas

pitrou commented on issue #3876: ARROW-4825: [WIP][C++][Python] Transition from MemoryPool* to shared_ptr<MemoryPool>&
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3876#issuecomment-473925622
 
 
   I'm a bit surprised by the choice to fix this on the Python side while the defect is obviously on the C++ side.
   
   I see two possible downsides with changing the C++ side:
   * API breakage: this is the main problem with the change
   * Potential performance issues: those sound a bit more unlikely
   
   One can indeed decide to store a middleman `shared_ptr<MemoryPoolImpl>` instead of `shared_ptr<MemoryPool>`. It has the same potential performance issues, doesn't break the API (AFAICT), but makes life harder for memory pool implementors.
   
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

wesm commented on issue #3876: ARROW-4825: [WIP][C++][Python] Transition from MemoryPool* to shared_ptr<MemoryPool>&
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3876#issuecomment-473977653
 
 
   @pitrou it would probably be best to discuss this further on the mailing list. IMHO the `MemoryPool` is a key property of the runtime environment. Having a huge number of objects "sharing ownership" of the MemoryPool does not seem useful to me. That it is possible to:
   
   * Create a MemoryPool
   * Allocate a Buffer with it
   * Destruct the MemoryPool
   * subsequently Segfault on deallocation of the Buffer
   
   is not a defect, instead that is how the project was explicitly designed. I don't even think this behavior is even bad, since this case indicates that an application has improperly looked after the lifetime of the MemoryPool. 
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

   Closing this PR for now. My view is that it is the application's responsibility to steward the lifetime of a MemoryPool. We can discuss further on the mailing list

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
Consider the following test function:

```
def test_memory_pool():
    import pyarrow as pa
    pool = pa.logging_memory_pool(pa.default_memory_pool())
    buf = pa.allocate_buffer(10, memory_pool=pool)
```

that will fail with segfault when `pool` is garbage collected before `buf`. However, the following test function succeeds:

```
def test_memory_pool():
    import pyarrow as pa
    pool = pa.logging_memory_pool(pa.default_memory_pool())
    buf = pa.allocate_buffer(10, memory_pool=pool)
    del buf
```

because all buffers are freed before `pool` destruction.

To fix this issue, the pool instance should be attached to buffer instances that the pool is creating. This will ensure that `pool` will be alive until all its buffers are destroyed.
fields.summary: [Python][C++] MemoryPool is destructed before deallocating its buffers leads to segfault

comments.body:
So, as pointer out by [~wesmckinn], the pool is already attached to the Buffer instances but via MemoryPool pointer.

Confirming that the change from `MemoryPool*` to `std::shared_ptr<MemoryPool>&` in relevant functions fixes the issue.

Although, this change needs to be applied to all of Arrow C++ source codes that use MemoryPool (there are alot), it seems a right thing to do.
